The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE SITUATION IN CHINA.
div.p: The sentiment and the movement denote by the cry "China for the Chinese" appear be growing both in force and range Telegram from Shanghai show that a strong agitation being carried on by the Chinese in that eit against an important railway concession sequi ed by an English company. The proposed lin will branch southwards from the road no under construction between Shanghai an Nanking, and will serve to link together th systems of Kiangsu and Chekiang province

According to a preliminary agreement, made in 1898, the right to finance the undertaking belongs to a British syndicate, but great difficulty has been found in obtaining a permanent arrangement on the question The Chinese Government even went so far, # year or two ago, as to authorise the provincial officials to build the railway. Now, when the Peking ralers have been induced to see the advisability of observing their treaty obligations, local foeling is violently opposing any surrender to the toreigner. It is somewhat omincus to learn that the native merchants are preparing to boyoott British goods in order to enforce their views Those who remember the serious crisis in Shanghai in December, 1905, will recollect that a similar step preceded the violent riots, which for some time threatened the safety of the foreign community. The difficulty of dealing with such manifestations of popular excitement lies in the fact that they are inspired by : strong and growing feeling. In the past Chinese opposition to railway enterprise was largely due to ignorance and to bigoted prejudice against innovation. Now the nation is growing awake to the necessity for progress and development, but the people are jealous of foreign interference and hostile to foreign influence, says the "Morning Post." National feeling is developing, and many of the educated class, especially the young students trained abroad, inspire and direct the opposition to foreign interests. Not only do they wish that all future development should be carried out by Chinese capital and under Chinese management, but they advocate the cancellation or redemption of existing concessions, and even demand the abolition of extra-territoriality at the Treaty Ports. This feeling has produced the bitter opposition to the Peking Syndicate in Shansi Province. It led to angry demonstra tions against the Canton-Kowloon concession, and it is blocking the way of numerous railway and mining enterprises in other parts of China. Even Japan has found her policy and aims in Manchuria thwarted. A number of questions, petty but troublesome, have led of late to. much negotiation and discussion between Chinese and Japanese representatives, and keen vexation, not to say exasperation, has been caused in Japan by the unyielding and obstructive attitude of the Chinese. That the Chinese, in their bitter hostility to the foreigner, are acting in opposition to their true interests seems beyond question. Their object, at least the object of the more enlightened section, is to follow in Japan's footsteps, to reorganise China and to make her great and powerful nation. Without foreign assistance and instrnetion, however, this goal will not be easily reached. It was only by welcoming the so operation of Western races that the Japanese made their marvellous advance during the last thirty years. Among the instruments, likely to promote the enlightenment and development of the Chinese nation, searcely any is so important as the introduction of easy and rapid means of communiostion through the Empire. Lack of internal cireulation bas probably been largely responsible for the stagnation of gifted race in the past. The vast extent of the Empire and the many differences between the component parts have prevented any real sense of pity and rendered the problems of administration difficult in the extreme. Some time ago a telegraph system was established over the Empire ; more recently the Chinese Post Office, organised by Sir Robert Hart, has been extending its operations. But railway development is as yet only beginning. And without foreign assistance its advance must be seriously retarded. China has not as yet either the capital or the engineers to build all the lines she requires. The blanders and mismanagement that have prevented the progress of the construction of the great Canton-Hankow line, redeemed from an American company at a heavy price, do not promise any satisfactory results from purely Chinese enterprises. To oppose all foreign co-operation would therefore seem unwise and shortsighted, even from the standpoint of purely Chinese interests. And, if the Chinese repudiate their engagements now, they may find themselves deprived of assistance when they most require it. On the other hand, it should be possible for British concession-holders to recognise Chinese sus ceptibilities, and where possible to make such arrangements as may satisfy the wishes of a proud and sensitive race. Those who know the Chinese say that, rightly approached, they are generally willing to effect a compromise. It the Chinese can be satisfied that the Baropean bas no rapacious designs upon their country, that, on the contrary, external assistance will promote its progress and prosperity, there may still be many opportunities for Western enterprise to assist in opening and developing an Bmpire, which in extent of territory and variety of resources is probably second to none.

div.head: Hellopolls Oasis
div.p: It has been decided not to finish the houses now under construetion on the Heliopolis Oasis until the drainage system is complete. There is to be one central purifying station, Every house in the Oasis will be fitted with an up to date drainage installation. The Garden City is already partly inhabited. The construction of the earthwork on the railway has been commenced.

div.head: Plague In Egypt
div.p: During the week ending the 16th November 22 cases of plague have occurred in Egypt. 11 of these proving fatal. The largest number of cases occurred at Aga where there were 12 cases under treatment, four cases came under treatment at Simbel a wein, three at Alexandria, one at Tantah, one at Mallawi, and one at Simallout. This brings the total for the year to 1164 ap to the 19th November, two cases having oecurred with in the last 24 hours. From January the 1st to November 18th last year only 529 cases had been under treatment.

div.head: Cold Imports Returns
div.p: The current number of the British Chamber of Commerce's monthly bulletin contains an interesting article on bullion returns during September in which it urged the Director General of Customs to publish the returns more frequently than once a month. We are glad to note that the suggestion of the British Chamber of Commerce has met with a favourable response and that the promise has been made to them that from 26th inst, the gold returns of imports for the preceding week will be posted op at the central cash office of the Customs Administra tion every Tuesday

div.head: What is a Mummy?
div.p: A mummy lying at the Paris Morgue is the cause of a dispute between the police, who insist that it is an unidentified corpse, and the owner, who is quite sure that it is a piece of furniture. The dispute, the "Mail" says, is the sequel to a fire in a flat. The firemen fonnd the mummy amid the ruins of a enp board. It was placed in a sack and conveyed to the Morgue "for identification. The owner of the flat has done everything possible to get it hack. But the police reply to all fepresentations with the question, "Is a mummy a corpse, yes ór no!" "Yes," says the owner, "but"There is no but," declare the police, "a mummyis a corpse, and this is the place of corpses."

div.head: Dangerous Practical Joking,
div.p: Considerable alarm was aroused in Sherif Pasha street, Alexandris, shortly after four o'clock yesterday afternoon, and the foot passengers within call of Messrs. Borman's and Co. 'were placed in some danger of serious injury with the possibility of loss of life. Happily, however, what might have proved a serious danger passed without incident of note and therely caused great excitement. An Arab leaving Borman and Co.'s stores with a cask of whiskey slipped and broke not only the case but its contents. For a space of about twenty yards the pathway was soaked in the spirit, and some mischievous youth'dropped on to the in active flood a lighted match which quickly caused an extensive blaze. Happily there were few persons on the pathway and the spirit burned out before any harm was done.

div.p: BRITISH CONSULAR CASES
This morning two interesting cases we theard at the British Consular Court, Ale andria, in which the plaintiffs were Briti subjeets, shareholders in the Bourse al Banking Company of Egypt Limited.

In the first case the plaintiff was represen ed by Mr. Reginald Silley, barrister at law, an the defendant company by Mr. Devonshir The plaintiff had been allotted 200 shares the Company which be sold at & premicm P. Subsequently, on the announcement the the bearer warrants were ready, plaintiff applie through the Anglo-Egyptian bank for deliver of same. He was requested by the company sign a form in accordance with the regulations the Alexandria Bourse, or otherwise the compan would not make the delivery. The plainti filled up the form, expunging the words "acoor ing to the Alexandria Bourse requirements Mr. Silley submitted that such condition in th form was unfair and interfered with the right of private contract and, therefore, the compan, is improperly retaining the warrants. Mi Devonshire contended that Art. 47 of th
on pany's statutes fally empowered the direc tors to determine the conditions upon whic the bearer warrants should be issued and t settle the form of application for the same.

The Court beld that the directors were no justified in attaching such condition and gav judgment for the plaintiff for the delivery a the warrants or £200 and costs. The plaintit Hid not press for damages.

The second case was an application for th memoval of the liquidator appointed at the meeting of the shareholders and the appoint ment of a liquidator nominated by the Court Mr. Devonshire, who represented the company contended that the court had (1) no jurisdio cion under section 12 of the Order in Council, (2) no jurisdiction in that the circumstances do not admit of same under
ection 107 of the Order unless, under section 167, the Secretary of State for Foreign Affair hould make an order covering a case where he circumstances do not permit.

The Court held that the question at issue Tell within jurisdiction as the plaintiff is a British subject and the defendant company of the same nationality, whereby the Mixed Courts could have no jurisdiction. Counsel for che defence gave notice of appeal, This appeal will probably be heard at the forthcoming sessions of the Supreme Court

The case is of importance as it affects all the many British companies registered under the Companies acts having their scope in Egypt, but whose boards may comprise either wholly or partly subjects of other Powers

div.head:
THE SUDAN
ITS POLITICAL STATUS.
div.p: A very important position has lately been ken up by the Ottoman Authorities at ddah, which is tantamount to an uncontional acknowledgment by Turkey of Bngnd's paramooney in the Sudan. The Imperial toman Government has allowed goods to ter Jeddah from Egypt and Turkey at the I rate of eight per cent. According to the test on yention goods from other countries ist pay eleven instead of eight per cent. ile the old rate prevails in the case of ports from Turkey and Egypt. Great imrtance therefore was attached to the attitude Sieh the Ottoman Authorities would take

in regard to the Sudan If it was acknow iged to be part of Egypt the duty would thain at eight per cent, but if the Porte knowledged that it no longer belonged to wypt eleven per cent would be levied. cently some corn was sent from Port Sudan

Jeddah and the Ottoman Authorities icially dedared that inasmuch as the Sudan * in no way connected with or formed part Egypt, a duty of eleven per cent had to be id. Considerable political importance obviwly attaches to this decision.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN POLITICS
THE MODERATES AND EXTREMISTS
div.p: There is a great deal of somewhat heated discussion proceeding in native circles in Cairo on the subject of the proposed Islamic Con gress. Party feeling runs so high now that it has even infected the lofty aims of the enthus iasts, who propose convening a congress at Csiro with a view to the reform of Islamic institutions. Mustapha Pasha Kamel obstin. ately refuses to serve on the committee, of which the Moderate Nationalists, represented by Sheikh Aly Youssef, of "Al Monyad," and Hafiz Effendi Awad, of "Al Mimbar," are members. The reason is parely personal, for Kamel still chafes and ever will bear renconr against the men, who are supported by the Englfish radicals in the House of Commons. The bitterest rebuff that Kamel has received has been this repudiation by the Egyptian Parliamentary Committee in the House of Commons and by the Aborigines Protection Society, both of which have given their support to the moderate Nationalists. Another very bitter pill," which Kamel has had to swallow was the entertainment, which was given to Sheikh Aly Youssef and Hafiz Effendi Awad during their visit to London this summer. He was specially infuris. ced when he heard that these two had received che high and exceptional honour of being invited to a sumptuous repast at the Mansion House by Sir William Treloar, the late Lord Mayor of London. When this news reached Kamel he could scarcely credit it and was

till more enraged when he learnt that the Lady Mayoress was taken arm in arm to the manquet by Sheikh Aly Youssef and that Hafiz Effendi Awad had a seat at the other end of the able next to the Lord Mayor and that they all conversed cordially during the whole of the mtertainment. The climax of Kamel's wrath Tas attained when he was informed that the word Mayor, without rising from his seat made

graceful address of welcome to his guests, explaining that it was not in accordance with recedent for him at such a private réunion to eliver a formal address, but that he wished the Egyptians present to understand that he Beeived them with sentiments of great cordiaty and that he trusted that they would eturn to their country with very agreeable eminisences of their visit to England. The

heikh replied in a few well chosen words of n equally informal, but of a no less cordial haracter, thanking the Lord Mayor for the exceptional honour accorded to him and his riend, adding that such honour, when the
gyptians at home heard of it, would be joymily accepted by his fellow-countrymen.
All this has been faithfully repeated to Camel, who considers it almost as a personal

front that when he was over in the preceding nummer he was not invited to the Mansion louse. Under the circumstances therefore he annot join the movement for the reform of alam and the Nationalist Achilles intends to olk in his tent so long as his hated rivals erve on the committee for the convening of me Congress.
THE PARTY OF THE PEOPLE.
The Party of the People has issued a manisto. It has not been published in "Al Gerida". at has been sent round to a number of people
the hope of getting adherents. It is a very maint production and sounds like a declaration
the rights of man of the French Revolution y Epoch. The vaguest and most elementary olitical truisms are given forth with a porten
us solemnity. After this comes an enuncia on of their policy, wherein the claim they absoite independence of Egypt here and now. This
going one better than the extremists asmuch as Kamel only claims independce subject to the limitation of the firm

and conventions at present in force. hether this very extreme policy will gain any adherents remains to be seen, but e manifesto has naturally caused mach noyance to the other Nationalists and it is mewhat difficult for them to know what new
e of policy to take up in order to go one itter.
It is very remarkable that the Party of e People was originally started by the lowers of Sheikh Mohamed Abdou and were
subject of a eulogy in Lord Cromer's last port, (page 8, chapter on Egyptian Nation
ANOTHER NEW PARTY.

A fresh cause of commotion has been the mour that a new Nationalist Party may not probably shortly take the field. This is the rty of the Republican Nationalists, who will mand the immediate constitution of a free
independent Egyptian Republie as an tonomous state. Nothing is as yet known as
the constitution of this party or as to ether they will found a newspaper to advoe their views.

div.head: NOTES TO TOURISTS.
div.p: 18. BEHAVIOUR TOWARDS DRAGOMANS
of
A correspondent writes :iro It is a regrettable but nevertheless a positiv 0-fact that out of the thousands of tourists wh it visit Egypt every year, and we are speakin
more particularly of the English tourist, but
very small percentage appear to have th nie slightest idea of the deportment and behaviou
required if they would retain the respect of th
native. The English tourist, who has unfor odtunately been the subject of well-earne md ridicule even in Europe, appears to lose entire
recommand of himself as soon as he sets foot in For the East, and gives way to a rowdyism which
or would astonish no one more than himself were g he guilty of such conduct at home, or if the

charge of rowdyism is not always applicable to en him, his manner is only changed to one of ry contempt blended with familiarity in his deal byings with the native, which is galling alike to of both Baropeans and Egyptians.

Who has not blushed to watch our country oh men and women in their effusive greetings and m-hand shakings with dragomen who are often of ef so doubtful a character that the meanest to Effendi in the streets would scarcely deign to
speak to them, who has not witnessed the nd excited and perspiring tourist waging a wordy
war with a mob of wrangling donkey boys un opposite our great hotels, or seen them duly d mounted galloping off, a shrieking and undig

nified crowd, seemingly possessed with the one | idea of attracting attention however anfavourheable. el Could these people only hear the remarks it of the very natives, who in their whimsical de conceit they imagine have been impressed with
their noise and inanity, hear how one donkey ve boy will vie with another in the circulating of the stories not of foolishness only. bat osten of a
character far more grave, I faney that they e would pause and wonder whether after all

they were acting in such a soul stirring manner has they had intended. 10 Most unfortunately the blame is not attachdable to the male tourist alone. We have female e visitors of a class which, however eminently
respectable they may be at home, certainly al appear to import none of its attributes into
this country, with the inevitable result that e year by year the respect which was hitherto
accorded to the white women who visit Egypt 1 grows less and less, and it is not an uncommon ething now to hear epithets of the coarsest
nature applied to the generality of English lady tourists.
Of course the majority, the great majority are blameless, and I have no doubt but what many of the indiscretions which occur are
solely the outcome of the ignorance which 3) prevails among the ordinary tourist regarding
the character of the native with whom they have to deal, people who are unsecustomed to Bastero standards being far too readily inclined to treat the native either with the scant
courtesy of a despot to his slave, or with a f|fulsome familiarity which immediately fosters
contempt and impertinence in the minds of those who are accustomed to receive it at the hands of their social equals or inferiors only.

It is as yet early in the season and there are not many tourists in the country in comparsion with the numbers which arrive later in the year, bat let us beg of those who have already settled themselves here for the winter, to guard themselves from the imputations of almost eriminal foolishness which it has become common to bestow and with justice upon a large number of our annual visitors. The man or woman whom the native dragoman respects is not to be found among those who grasp his hand in a cordial grip and accompanies bim about the town like a friend and brother. The code of the native servant here demands nothing of the sort, any more than does one's butler at home, the native extends his band to his superior as an act of homage, it being sufficient to touch it only in return. The dragoman shonld be made to walk a. little way in advance of, or behind his master, never together as equals, and it is neither dignified or efficacions to take the prominent part in street brawls between donkey boys which some of our countrymen appear to think is demanded of them.
The above remarks apply only to the dealing with dragomen and servants. With the higher classes it is of course different, but with these the ordinary tourist has little or nothing to do.

Tourists already bere would be doing the country a great service if they would try and instil into the minds of the later arrivals the fact that the old proverb "familiarity breeds contempt" is as potent in its meaning in this country as it is at home.

div.head: THE CAIRO SEASON.
div.p: Among the many signs of the beginning of the Cairo Benson is the opening of the fashion able Savoy Hotel, which is on Monday next. A large number of well-known English and foreign people have already booked rooms. Among those due soon are the Earl and Countess of Rothes, with a large party, incleding Lady Mildred Leslie, Mr. W. Baird, Captain and Mrs. Devenish MacGill Crichton and Mrs. and Miss Pellows. They embark at Marseilles on the P.&0. S.S. Macedonia" on the 12th proxo. After a stay at the Servoy they will go up the Nile on their way to Khartoum. Major Collins, of the Scots' Greys, and Lady Margaret Collins are due at the Savoy in the first week in the December. They are on their honeymoon. Mrs. Hague Cook, Mr. and Mrs. Fletcher, Mr. Randolph Berens, Mr. Richard S. Raphail, of Berkeley Square, London, Captain Beddington, ofthe Queens lancers, Aldershot, Miss Cochrane, who come to the Savoy every year, are all due early next month.

div.head: CLAWED BY A LEOPARD.
div.p: Suez, Tuesday. s! Yesterday afternoon while number o of persons were on board the Khedivial Mail line el "Prince Abbas", looking at some leopards
giraffes, ete, which had arrived from Port Sudan e in transit for Genoa, Miralai Snow Bey's little - daughter approached too near one of the cage
containing the leopards, and one of them got rehold of the child's leg with its claws, but
fortunately, owing to the prompt assistance of of the bystanders, the child was rescued, though
not before several scratches more or less slight
were inflicted. These were at once attended m to by the ship's doctor, and today I am pleased - to hear that she is not suffering much pain.
Shortly after the accident, the chief of the police proceeded on board, and opened an enquiry, which was attended by a represen
tative of the Italian Consulate, the keepen m being an Italian subject.

div.head:
FATAL POLO ACCIDENT.
BRITISH OFFICER KILLED.
div.p: We are sorry to report a very bad sceident that occurred to Captain Roberts whilst play ing in the poło tournament yesterday afternoon. It appears that when riding off an opponent Capt. Robert's pony crossed its legs, tarned a complete somersault, and then rolled over bim. So far as is known at present the injuries are bad corttassion and a seriously fractured left arm. Capt. Roberts was still unconscious at 6 o'clock, but general symptoms were more favourable. This tournament has proved an unlucky one, Sir Walter Barttelot injuring his wrist, and yesterday, the 18th, Mr. Watts Russell's pony fell down dead from heart failure after finishing a chukker. Mr. Watts Russell has our sincere sympathy for it was his best pony, which after playing a chukker in its usual game way staggerred and fell dead.
The King's Royal Rifle Corps bave presented a handsome eup for the regimental tournament, a gift which is highly appreciated by all of our polo players.
Later, Y We much regret to announce that Captain Roberts died last night from the injuries received through his accident.

div.head: POSTAL REFORMS
div.p: De
he
To Tax EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAS GAZETTE"
Sir, I have noticed recently in your columns st letters under the heading of postal reforms and
though I am fully in agreement that the reform es demanded is necessary, it is, I am sure, by no ne means the most necessary and, moreover, is
due more to local mismanagement than to faulty bel postal administration.
While, however, the administrators are seek t ing suggestions which will improve the general mosphere covered by the administration I would
like to offer one, which will be accepted as sound by the general public and as entirely
reasonable by those hard-worked officials who to are the batt of criticism, just and unjust.
It concerns the inland money order. Why cannot we have postal orders such as are our
rent at home! Sapposing one wishes to send e by post an order for, say, P.T. 20. To do so it to. is necessary to fill in a forn which requires the is sender to state the following :-Name and sur

name of sender; Name, surname, and profes. sion of payee; Office of destination; Amount in figures; Amount in letters; Date; Signature of sender. In these days of labour saving why should an administration go contrariwise to the rest of the world and creste unnecessary labour. Time is money, is our present day maxim, and surely one should not have to go to the trouble of writing a lengthy book every time one desires to send a shilling or eighteen pence to a neighbobr by means of the post office. We should be able to put our coin on the counter and immediately receive paper in exchange without Tesorting to the pen at all.
Your obedient servant

div.head: CAIRO'S DRAINAGE.
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir.- I have of late been visiting Cairo and have been greatly interested in the problem of the drainage of Egypt's capital. Undoubtedly in the person of Mr. Carkeet James, Egypt possesses one of the most eminent specialists in Oriental drainage and as an old Anglo Indian I can testify to his ability and to the enormous difficulties which he has to encounter in the present instance. The difficulties, which he had to encounter in Bombay, are much on par with the problems which confront bim in Cairo. If Mr. James is determined to solve the riddle once and for all, he should brush aside all ephemeral financial interest and be per mitted to deal with the question of the site of the sewage farm on his own absolute responsi bility. This question is of vital importance to Cairo and its inhabitants, as it was in the case of Calcutta. Cairo death rate is far too high and a great deal of this mortality must be ascribed to its atter lack of a drainage system. The city is being rapidly developed and will soon become one of the greatest centres of population in the world. The old adage that "time is money" is of far less significance than its more modern variant "Life is money." It is essential that this question should be solved once and for all and it only Mr. Carkeet Jamesbe allowed a free hand, I feel onfident that he will be capable of effecting a solution. In many cases in England sewage schemes have been carried out, which are based on the following tour successive processes: (1) Screening (2) Precipitation of the detritas. (8) Treatment of the ensuing eficent in anaerobie bacterial tanks. (4) 'Intermittent downward filtration. Such is the system, which might (with 'advantage be followed in Cairo and from per sonal, experience, I can guarantee that, if this system be adopted, it will cause no naisance even to those in the immediate neighbourhood.
Truly Yours

div.head:
THE AMERICAN CRISIS
PANAMA CANAL BONDS.
ABSURDITY OP PANIC.

div.p: The Panama Canal bonds will bear 2 % interests and will be redeemable after ten years, at the pleasure of the Government. The Treasury certificates will bear 3 %. The latter will be issued at par. This action is heartily approved by President Roosevelt, who says that the leaders of Congress are considering & curreney measure which will permanently meet the needs of the situation. It appears that the people realize the fundamentally sound business conditions of the country and the absurd ity of panic and boarding
The relief measures are having an excellent effect on the stock markets." (Renter)

FRANCE AND GERMANY

div.p: The newspapers have displayed no feeling against the German Emperor's visit. On the contrary several of them point out that it may contribute to greater friendliness between Germany and France through the mediatory influence of Great Britain.

div.head: THE BAGHDAD RAILWAY.
div.p: The Times of India," discussing the Baghdad railway scheme, in connection with the German Emperor's visit to England, urges that any fresh proposals for the construction of the line should be considered impartially. The old terms on which British co-operation was invited were absurd. Acceptable conditions, the journal adds, would include British control of the section between Baghdad and the ses, and possibly of that between Baghdad and Kahnikin, while traffic on the Tigris would have to be regulated, so as to prevent undercutting of the railway in the matter of rates.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: It is now pretty well known that Sir Charles C. Drury will put in the regulation period as Commander in Chief of the Mediterranean Fleet. The statement that he had been selected for the Devonport command is insecumte.
The hospital ship "Mains" will leave Portemouth on the 12th inst. to resume daty with the Mediterranean Fleet.
The only explanation forthcoming concern ing the 5th Lancers sensation is that some of the officers placed on half pay were originally
infantry officers and that their early training I was not favourable for cavalry work. The

alleged inefficiency of the regiment is indig-1 nantly repudisted on every side. In fact, whilst the Lancers were recently at Aldershot they were at the top of the tree practically for all round work.

It is intimated that there will be a modifica tion in next years' battle pratice. Towing targets will be utilised where possible, and an alteration will be made in the system of awarding points for hits. The value of say a 12 inch projectile hit and a 6 inch projectile hit will be comparative, additional value being given to the bit of the bigger gun in working out the ! results.

Captain R. M. P. Swift, Koyal Dublin Fusiliers, commanding a company in the 1st Battalion, Alexandrin, has got the vacant majority caused by the retirements of Major A. H. Rutherford. Major Swift attains that rank after nineteen years service as a subaltern and company commander. His war services em brace the relief of Ladysmith and the Transvaal operations generally (mentioned in des patches, Queen's medal with five clasps, King's | modal with two clasps).

The 2nd Battalion Royal Dublin Pusiliers, Permoy, has received direetions to prepare a draft of 100 non-commissioned officers and men for despatch to the 1st Battalion at Alexandria. The draft will journey per the troopship "Soudan," along with the 1st Battalion of the Green Howards and some other troops, leaving South ampton on the 16th Jaguary next.

Captain R. P. Daltrymple, King's Royal Rifle Corps, joins the Egyptian Army to fill a yacancy. He has been connected with the Rifle Corps for eight years and did good work with the Mounted Infantry in the operations for the relief of Ladysmith, including the hard fighting on the Tagels, and in the campaign after wards, for which he holds the Queen's medal with five clasps, and the King's medal with two clasps.

Captain and Brevet Major H.G. Joly de Lotbiniere, Royal Engineers, doing daty at Cairo, has just been promoted to substantive field rank. Major Joly de Lotbiniere, who is one of the two soldier sons of Sir Henry G. Joly de Lotbiniere, K.C.M.G, ex-Lieutenant Governor of British Columbia, entered the

Royal Engineers in January, 1888, and was | promoted captain in 1891, and brevet major in: 1900. During the earlier phases of the South African War he was staff officer to the Director of Railways, and he was employed in connee tion with the railways during the greater part of the war, was superintendent of a native refugee camp for some time, and after the war was employed under the Transvaal Government. His services in the field ineluded the advance to Kimberley, operations in Orange Free State, in the Transvaal, east and west of Pretoria, and in Cape Colony (mentioned twice in despatches, brevet majority, Queen's medal with three clasps, King's medal with two clasps). Previous to the South African War he served with the Royal Engineers in the oper ations of 1897-98 on the North West Proutier, of India, including the sharp fighting on the Samana range, and in the Kurrsman Valley and the action of Dargai (medal with three clasps), and in the recent operatious against the "Mad Mullah" in Bast Afries he was | employed as a special service officer, and added
further to his reputation (medal with clasp, la mentioned in despatches).

div.head: THE MAMELUKE'S LEAP:
div.p: (On March 1st, 1811, Mohamed Ali, Pasha of Egypt, invited the Mameluke Emfes to a feast in the citadel as Cairo and massacred all of them sve one, Emin Bey, into whom mouth the following videre put
With clang of cymbals and rattle of drums,
In scarlet and in gold, My mates and I went forth to die
In the heart of the Pashae holl There was never voice to Hd us stay
There was never a warning word, But the press of his feast were the unelean beast
And the wide winged seven ger bird. But when we rode through the long besar
The traders al madde way, And far and near me shrank in fese
From the night of our array, As with clank of soabbard and clatter of hoof
We rode to the Pasha's board, The cream and power of the Mamelake power,
The master of the sword: When as we came to the eltadel ramp
The sun was red and high, But we looked our last der his light was passed
Upon God's good earth and sky For as we rode up the citadel lace
(And steep it is to ride) The way was blocked and the gates were locked,
And death was on either side. The Pasha's soldiers lined the road, 7 Wild men from over ses, To left and right, in kirtles white,
With guns and musketry: Small hope was there to sale the walls
That frowped on either hand, From overhead the flying lead
Macle mook of steed and brand, Our blades leapt out, our heels drove home,
We galloped to and fro, But never man from tear to van
Could reach the mooking foe. The red sparks flew from our chargers' hoofs,
The narrow roadway rangi With ourse and groan, with the bullet' money
And armour's clask and clang. For me, I had passed the upper gute
Or ever the fray began And hand on haft I tumed and laughed
As the murderers fired and I drove my mare to the platform wide
Where the black guns stand e-row, With a shake of the rein I purred amsin
And leapt to the desort below A jarting crash and a whirl of and
-It was fifty feet and more And my mare lay dead, but I rose and dat,
Though body and heart were sore Through the Tomb of the Kings and the desert sandt
Till I met with a caravan And far from the ken of the Paste's mer
I dwell in Wordofans Now the one of God and the People of Gode
The ourse of the Bevon Imame, Lie heavy as lead on the Pasha's head
And onshof his dog Nisan But magn and water of Perhe
Bas the lot of my good grey mare, Wha bore meoler from that house of When my comrades perished there !
J. L. Ksiostanks, in the "Spectator

div.head: ÆGYPTIACA.
div.p: THE TOMB OF IOUIYA AND TOUIYOU

One of the most sumptuons books apo Egyptian Antiquities ever produced is the "Tomb of louiya and Touiyou" which describe the now celebrated discovery of the Sepulchr of the parents of Queen Tiyi for which scieho is indebted to Mr. Theodore M. Davis.

The publishers Messrs. Archibald Constable & Co, are to be congratulated upon the super! volumn which for the first time utilises th best modern process of colour printing for the reproduction of ancient Egyptian art specimens

The literary portion of the book proceed from the pens of Professor Gaston Maspero and Mr. Perey Newberry so that its value i assured. The first of these provides a ful description of the titles of the two occupanta of the tomb, explaining the various hierogly phical methods of spelling their names, and also the different Offices of rank which are assigned to them: louiya having been a feadal noble, or Rapaiti haiti : and Samirou a priestly function. He was also a member of the corps of courtiers called "Friends of the King" indeed be was very exalted in the guild for be is called "The first friend of the friends." At one time probably when not such an important personage he had been "Prophet of Mip" and superintendent of the oxen of the same god. Numerous honorific titles are added symbolising the regard in which he was held by the King ; terminanting by the statement that his coffin was made by the King's special favour.

Toniyou at various times had been "Chantress of Amon" "Dresser to the King "Lady of the harem (priestess) of Min," and so on, but her special honorific which is most frequently repeated on objects belonging to her found in the tomb was to have been "Royal mother of the chief wife of the King" that is mother in-law of Amenophis III. Many of their honours were probably heaped upon these comparatively private individuals by the Pharaoh subsequent to his marriage of their daughter and were sinecure offices, for as far as we know they never took any part in state affairs. The most important part of the Professor Maspero's introduction however is wherein he disposes once for all of the infoanded theory that Queen Tiyi was of Asiatie origin. As he says after fully discussing the question :- "Everything cohsidered, the hypothesis of Syrian origin for Queen Tiyi rests upon a collection of mistaken theories or badly interpreted facts, and as she herself was the only reason for making louiya and Touiyou foreigners the desire to make them other than Egyptian must be renounced at once. Equally their titles coneet them with Egyptian sacred rites."

It is interesting to note that according to the newly found text upon her sarcophagus, Touiyon had another child as well as Tiyi, a son, who was & Prophet of Ammon. The description by Mr. Theodore Davis of the discovery of the tomb reads like a romance. He gives excellent reason for thinking that the penetration of it by a robber was the work of someone familiar with its construction, and so took place soon after the interment. The their came for the sake of the gold, and probably had a very poor light for his sacriligious work for he carried off the inner chamber a large scarab of stone, the neck yoke of the chariot and a baton, all of which were covered with gold leaf, but reaching a part of the corridor where daylight showed him that they were not solid metal, he dropped them as not being worth taking further He also left a large gold plate in the breast of one of the mummies and many small gold heads and ornaments.

This tomb is the first, of personages connected with royalty, ever found intact for with the gold ornaments removed by the early robber every article originally walled up in the sepulchre was there in some cases tumbled in the search for the precious metal it is true, as in the case of the two sets of triple coffins these having been taken apart and the lids of the innermost ones removed to get at the mummies. As is well known to the visitors to the Cairo Museum all the contents of the tomb, except a few objects Mr. Theodore Davis was permitted to retain, are displayed in a special salon in the gallery and form the greatest treasure of Egyptian Art in the world, A description of some of these, especially the splendid and perfect chariot of which much can be said, is reserved for a forture instalment of "Aegyptiacs." In enelusion it is worthy of remark that the recovery of the bodies of louiya and Touiyou is due to generous efforts of a citizen of the land of the far west all unknowń to the contemporaies of Amenophis and Tiyi but which occupies the position or their longed for "Armenti" the abode of the blessed in the land of the west where the isles of that occidental sea were laved by the beams of Ra Osiris, the setting sun.
EGYPTIAN RESEARCHES IN SYRIA.

The Universite of Saint Joseph at Beyrouth Thas now published the second eduwe of Me langes written by the Professorsát the Faculte Orientale" of the College. As was the case with the first volume many of the essays relate to matters concerning Egypt, or to contiguous countries, and so we again refer to the matters of interest to our Egyptian readers: Père Mallon gives a further instalment of his history of "Une Ecole de savants Egyptiens an moyen Age" this time, studying the chief Coptie Grammarians, mostly Cairenes, in the 14th century. Especially the famous Abou Saker Ibn-ar Rabeb from one of whose unedited philological treatises long extracte are given. A more than usually useful vocabulary giving the Arabic meanings of Coptic words is that of Aboul-Barakat-; because instead of confirming his, work to words in the liturgical books and seriptures s al all Coptio lexicographers he imposses no lim to his researches and commencing with titles of the Deity descends down to the me est animals, and collects all words both scient and vulgar, as Père Mallon says, more in spirit of the French Eneyclopædists than of Egyptian mediaevalist. He was at times bot priest and a medical man and during part of career acted as secretary to the Sultan Baiba He died in A.D. 1363 leaving his "So Magns" in 10 Books and 32 Chapters, conta ing all the knowledge as to words and th meanings erudite Egyptian could obtain at era. Manuscripts more or less complete of work are at Paris, London, Oxford, M chester, and Rome. There is one at Cai number 1492 M. in the Library of the Cop | Patriarch, and may be consulted there. | Another of these authors was Abou Ish and Père Mallon prints in Arabic, and translation, a curious introduetion by him his "Scala Rimée."

An important essay by P. L. Cheik endeavours to complete the list of the bisha of Sinai; some 14 of these are known butan Arabie mannseript preserved in the Mou Sinai convent of St. Catherine and written A.D. 1710 much amplifies the list.

The most valuable contributions in t volume of Mélanges is the further list a edition of new Greek and Latin inscriptio from Syria by the Abbé Louis Jalabert. T chief text is a dedication to the Emper Julian found near Beyrout, bat, for reade of the "Egyptian Gazette" the most useful pa of the work is the account of all kno ancient inscriptions concerning the worsh of Serapis in Syria. The Serapis cult at on time obtained a certain vogue in Syria in the other part of the Roman world; a fa not surprising when it is remembered wh intimate relations existed between Syria an Egypt. But strange to say epigraphic eviden of this is very scanty and the Abbé Jalabe can only collect some 8 texts and one these relating to certain recluses, or temp residents, in the shrine of Jupiter at Baetoce does not mention Serapis but from the simil titles applied to these personages to that use of what are called the "Recluses of the Ser peum" at Memphis, the Abbé Jalabert thin that the cult of Serapis must have been unite with that of Jupiter at the Syrian Temple.

div.head: SIR GILBERT PARKER'S EGYPTIAN ROMANCE
div.p: There are two points of interest in s Gilbert Parker's new novel, which he describe as "A tale of England and Egypt 50 years ago. In the first place he has pictured the conditio of Egypt as it was before the days of th British Occupation, and given us a vivid ide of the difficulties which would face anyon attempting to substitute purity in administra ition and a more comfortable life for the fellahi in place of the then prevalent oppression corraption, and intrigue. In so doing he ha helped us to more fully realise the complete mess of the success achieved by one who no many months ago concluded his life's work i Egypt.

In the second place, the central figure a the story is unquestionably based upon a mai whose character and career always grip th imagination, viz. General Gordon. In reading of the doings and sayings of David Claridg we have ever before our minds the history a Gordon in China, and the Soudan. The story will not, however, rank among the author' best works. It is too much drawn-out, and some of the descriptions are inclined to be wearisome. Claridge is a somewhat unres personage, and several of the "incidents" con nected with his career are too improbable even for a romance. For instance, we are not con

inced that the scheming and unscrupulous Prince Hanik would be willing to commit ujeide by casting himself into his own den of Tons simply because he learns from the Prince Kaid's adviser that his plot against the ruling
rince had been discovered. We think he would require more practical evidence that all was lost than that of a man whose life he held is hand.

Nevertheless the narrative is a striking one. David Claridge, the son of quaker parents, as, at the time of the commencement of the tory, incurred the displeasure of the elders of the church by reason of his "worlåly" ten eneies. He receives his "eall" to Egypt on the death of his uncle, an eastern trader. His eculiar Quaker dress and mode of life quickly ring him into notice, and with a rapidity which is not a little extraordinary he is pro noted to the rank of "adviser to the Prince Kaid," much to the chagrin of the Armenian thristian, Nahoum Pasha, whom he supersedd. For years he labours to break down the ystem of misrule and corruption, but all ilong he is the victim of the intrigne of a lique at the palace. He does much good by elieving the poor, and providing them with emunerative employment

He ereeted two cotton mills, but they wese oth burned down by his ene nies. Later he med his attention to the Sudan, and led a ampaign against the slave dealers. Both he and is army are in mueb danger, and the subject t intervention by the British is raised in the House of Commons, and is strenuously oppos| by the Under Secretary of State for Foreign

ffairs, Lord Elglington, who is jealpus of Claridge. Subsequently he emerges safely from is dangers, and by one of those remarkable oincidences rarely met with outside the pages f a novel Claridge is proved to be the elder rother of the Earl of Elglington, and the real eir to the title. Thas everything ends happily.
Sir Gilbert Parker's descriptions of Egypt make fasinating reading, and he has proved that ne possesses an intimate knowledge of the rays of this wonderful country and its inabitants.
div.note: (* *The Weavers" by Sir Gilbert Parker. London 1 William Heineman.)

div.head: PERSIA.*
div.p: Mr. Williams is a pleasant companion wi whom to ride across Persia, and by his moral ings and quaint philosophizinge uneonscious makes himself the better known to one troubles himself little with the meaning a purport of the things he sees, has a faith his diary and a belief in the importance of e tracts from the poets that point to a youth yet deprived of glamour
Mr. Williams is impressed with the powe vested in a Persian Governor.

"When I was at Shiraz all the batchers we flogged in pairs because the price of meat w too high I believe they protested that she were dear, and that therefore they could well meat at a low price; whereon the Govern retorted that they had better wait to kill sheep until they were cheaper again. The me point was, however, that the price of meat ca
Mr. Williams was scoorded an audience the Governor of Shiraz. He shows the Bri fishman's customary impatience at the cen monial of the East.

"During conversation with the Governor it necessary to scrupulously observe certain foru of speech. Your title and his title must be ca rectly and frequently used. He will be, perhap "Hazarat-i-ali-"your bigh mightiness" ; yo *Bandeh-i-shuma"-"your slave."

"The interview will begin with the stereoty ed Mahometan greeting, "Peace be with thee n Arabic, and after that "your slave" mu wait for "your high mightiness's" next remar which will be an inquiry as to your slave's mealth. You will then retort, "The health Four slave, thanks to the proence of you aigh mightiness is very good. The health mour high mightiness, please Allah, is al mery good " "Your slave" will then be bidde o sit, and conversation will begin, during whic it is necessary to constantly remember the ou are a slave and that he is a high migh

As the time of Mr. Williams's visit was prio to the death of the late Shah and the inst ration of quasi-constitutional government, hi mook affords no fresh light on the trend vents in the East. Indeed, the author pay light heed to political developments, and more concerned with the superficut features ife and manners in Persia.
Mr. Williams gives a diverting account of oyal salaam at the palace of the Shahi Teheran. He found the statues of youn
dies in the famous royal gardens "unfor unately, owing to a flaw in the casting, por assed of a universally inebriated appearance.
the palace he found a room devoted to the resents brought by the Shah from Europe.

"In one corner is an untidy pile of velvet md ermines; close by a collection of very nterior photographs ; in the oppositi omer s beer-machme, on which reposes a il painting. . . . All is chaos negleet, pa netic waste. I leave with an ache at th eart-all this rich uselessness, and, outside - the people-poverty-desolation."

The soldiers were a bedraggled company ade formidable with bands. "I am not able to ascertain whether the arious bands are playing the same tunes fferent times or different tunes at the me time; but in either case the result is combination of discords vastly superior to at caused by the puny efforts of any invidual collection of instrumentalists sve yet met in Persia."
The helmets of the soldiers astonished his military mind until he was assured that they Pre useful "to guard against having one's
ad cut off - one of the most serious things at can happen to one in a battle." Yes, Mr. illiams is a very pleasing companion in eria

"Tribune."

div.head: BOVRIL
div.p: Qu'est ce que c'est BOVRIL?
BOVRIL est le produit garanti du meilleur bétail qui existe.
C'est un repas à la minute qui protège contre les intempéries.
"BOVRIL" et "Bonne Cuisine" sont deux mots qui disent la même chose.

BOVRIL répond a une nécessité; il est non seulement une boisson delicieuse et saine, mais il est encore indispensable pour préparer instantanement des soupes et sauces appétisantes. Bovril n'a pas de rival pour corser les plats les plus récherches.
BOVRIL répare l'organisme fatigué.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Délégation municipale s'est réunie le 19 novembre 1907 à 4 h. 1/2 p.m. sous la présidence de S.E. le Dr. Sebiess Pacha.
Etaient présents MM. Yehia Pacha Mansour Bey Youssef, Amb. A. Ralli, Soliman Bey Abani et G. Zervadachi, membres, W.P.Chata ways, administrateur, I. Sedky Bey, seorétaire général.
La Délégation procédle à l'examen du projet elaboré par le Service Sanitaire et tendant à la règlementation du colportage du lait en Ville.
Elle approuve ce projet en principe et décide de le communiquer au Comité du Contentieux.

De même elle émet an avis favorable à la règlementation proposée par le Service Sanitaire pour les hôtels d'un ordre tout à fait inférieur et décide de faire à ce sujet des propositions au Ministère de l'Intérieur.
La Délégation prend connaissance des devis relatifs à l'asphaltage du complément de la rue Rosette, devis qui s'élèvent environ à LE. 15,000.

Les dalles retirées de cette rue pourraient servir au pavage d'autres artères de la ville, dont l'exécution a été déjà décidée et la Mwnicipalité économiserait de ce shef les sommes nécessaires à l'acquisition de nouvelles dalles pour lesquelles un crédit de Leg. 7.500 est inserit au budget.
De ce fait il ne serait nécessaire de demander à la Commission Municipale qu'un nouveau crédit de Leg. 7.500.

Après avis du Comité des Finances, la Délégation décide de limiter pour le moment les travaux d'asphaltage de cette rue à concurrence du crédit budgétaire non employé de Leg. 7.500, sauf à continuer l'asphaltage de cette rue au fur et à mesure de nouvelles disponibilités.
Les travaux à exécuter dans ces conditions s'arrêteront au palais municipal.
La Délégation émet un avis défavorable sur une proposition d'une société concernant on arrangement à faire en vue de réserver à Gaet el Einab un emplacement pour le destructeur des immondioes.

La Délégation, à la suite des renseignements complémentaires fournis par les services, émet un avis favorable à la depense supplémentaire de L.B. 580 environ pour l'acquisition de fournitures de bureau, frais d'impression et frais divers.
L'Administrateur dépose son rapport sur le projet da budget 1908, lequel sera distribué à tous les Conseillers pour être examiné à une prochaine séance.
La séance est levée à 7 h. } p.m.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi) Notre marché a été comme hier privé de tout intérêt an point de vue transactionnel. Les échanges ont été insignifiants et limités à un petit groupe de valeurs : National Bank, Agricole, Comptoir, Estates, Investment et Gabbari Land. Mais il n'en est pas de même des fluctuations de la cote. Elles sont nombreuses et dénotent une reprise partielle plus ou moins sensible qu'on attribue à un retour de confiance dans les affaires américaines ainsi qu'à l'accentuation de la fermeté au Stock Exchange. Cette dernière hypothèse est d'autant plus plausible que ce sont nos valeurs dirigeantes cotées à Londres qui bénéficient principalement de la plus-value, tandis que pour nos titres d'ordre secondaire ou purement local le mouvement est loin d'être uniforme, quelques-unes continuant à perdre du terrain. Comme la suite dépend presque uniquement de l'allure que prendront les évènements tant en Angleterre qu'en Amérique, on conçoit qu'il soit difficile pour le moment d'émettre des hypothèses.

L'Agricole et la National Bank progressent la première de 7 25/32 à 7 13/16 et la seconde de 19 13/16 á 20. Eo hausse également la Delta Light de 9 5/8 à 9 11/16, la Daïra de 12 3/8 à 12 1/2, et l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 287 * 288 l'ancienne et de 251 1/2 4 262 la nouvelle.
Mieux tonas les Dividendes Tramways d'A. lexandrie se relèvent aussi de 260 A 263.

En revanche, la Ramleh fléchit encore de 4 1/4 à 4, la Behera de 20 1/2 à 20 1/4, les Dividendes Bière d'Alexandrie de 80 à 70 francs, la Société de Pressage de 30 à 28 £, et les Nungovich Hotels de 16 3/8 & 16 1/4.
On a inscrit pour la première fois à la cote officielle la Privilégiée Bébérs à 4 1/8.

Dans la catégorie des titres inférieurs les Markets rétrogradent de 25/6 à 25/-,les Cotton Mills de 1/6 à 1/3, la Salt and Soda de 15/3 a 15, la Cassa di Sconto de 44 à 43 francs, les Estates de 7/16 à 13/32 et la Building Lands de 1 11/16 à 1 5/8. Seule les Comptoir reprennent de 2 7/16 à 2 1/2 et la Levico de 5/16 à 11/32
La Gabbari Land a été traitée aux environs de 2 à 2 1/8.
Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de changements à signaler. La tendance en fait n'existe pas, puisqu'elle est entièrement subordonnee aux nouvelles du dehors. .

div.head: EASTERN TELEGRAPH CO. LTD.
div.p: AVERAGE TIME occupied in transmission of Egyptian telegrams from England to Alexandria on Tuesday, 11th July, 1905.
OUTWARDS.
Between the hours of 10 a.m. and 6 p.m. (Cairo time)
Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTRS BT CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Mardi 19 Novembre. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres es renseigné en baisse de 1/8 à 6 7/8 pou cent

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais haussé hier de 1/4 à 82 8/8. L'Unifiée s'es raffermie a 99. La National Bank a rétrograd de 1/8 à 19 7 8 et la Daira de 1/4 à 12 1/4 L'Agricole est restée inchangée à 7 7/8 et Delta Light à 9 7/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a gagn 7 francs à 677. La Banque d'Athènes a ét plus ferme à 108. Les Lots Tures ont été sou tenas à 168.

Ici, bien que Londres nous ait signalé quel ques velléités de meilleure allure dans la situs tion monétaire en même temps qu'une repris assez forte des Consolidés, notre marché n' pas enrayé sa tendance à la baisse, suivante cela l'exemple du groupe égyptien sur le mar ché anglais. Les transactions restent rares, de même que vendeurs et acheteurs. C'est l'apa thie qui règne, avec les nouvelles les plus fan tastiques. Malheureusement les gens crédale ne manquent pas en Egypte et l'on ajoute fo à des racontars dont on aurait souri en un autre moment.
Au demeurant, rien que d'insignifiant å si gnaler, à part un peu plus de termeté pour les petites valeurs et une recrudescence de tassement dans le groupe des Sociétés Fon cières. .
Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na tional Bank hausse de 1/16 à 19 15/16, tandis que l'Agricole s'alourdit à 7 13/16. Le Comp toir Financier est également plas faible as 3/8-7/16.

La Delta Light se tasse à 9 11/16. Les Jouis sances Eaux du Caire reculent encore à 158 La Daïrs Sanieh n'est pas plus soutenue à 19 3/8. L'obligation ancienne du Crédit Foncien Egyptien baisse à 287. La Béhéra perd toute son avance antérieurea 20 ; l'action privilégiée est lourde à 4-4 1 16. La Nile Land tombe à 8 La Compagnie Immobilière se raffermit à 285 Les Ciments perdent 3 francs à 29. Les Omni bus-Automobiles fléchissent à 2 3/16-1/4.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nangovich sont en perte de 1/4 à 16 1/4. Les Baehler con tinnent à rétrograder # 4 3/4 alors que les Upper Egypt se relèvent à 2 11/16-3/4.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land se ressaisit à 1 5/16. La New Egyptian est tou jours dépréciée à 9/3, ainsi que les fondateurs Estates & 2 18/16. Les Walker and Meimarachi s'inscrivent en recul à 05/16.

Le "Bulletin Mensuel du Swiss Bankverein" après avoir montré l'impossibilité pour les ban ques américaines de conserver une réserve er espèces proportionnée aux formidables dépôts qu'elles recevaient, puisque ceux-ci en 1886 s'élevaient à dollars 2,844,723,671, en 1896 dollars 4,945, 124,424 et en 1906 à dollars 12,215,767,066, expliqueque la erise américaine actuelle est due surtout au fait que les sommes tretirées des banques ne rentrent pas dans la circulation. Le retour de la confiance seul peut amener la fin de la crise par la rentrée en scène des énormes sommes pour le moment improductives.
II apprécie de la façon qui suit l'activité des Banques américaines dans le placement de leurs dépôts :

"En Amérique les dépôts, au dépens de leur sécurité, sont utilisés à produire des intérêts plus élevés qu'en Angleterre ; ils servent an Dommerce, à l'indostrie et à la spéculation. Ils sont, en conséquence, des facteurs efficaces dans le trafic économique, ils contribuent à son augmentation et à sa stimulation, mais ils eneou

ragent, d'autre part, l'inflation qui doit amener maturellement à une réaction et même & one catastrophe au cas oh des excès auraient été commis. Dans des cas semblables, il va sans dire, qu'en règle générale, des défauts sont mis au jour, et ont comme conséquences d'éveiller Ha méfiance et d'amener le public à retirer son soldedes établissements de dépôts. La méfiance, mune fois déchainée, ravage autour d'elle ainsi qu'une gangrène."
Hier a eu lieu une assemblée générale de la Corporation des Agents de Change du Caire.

Toutes les décisions prises durant l'été, conernant notamment la Chambre de Compensation et le marché à terme, ont été approuvées. Des remerciements ont été votés au Comité pour son activité pendant cette période difficile, et ce à l'onanimité moins une voix, ce qui prouve la solidarité de la Corporation.

Le Comité a été prié en outre d'aviser aux modifications à introduire dans le règlement Bu marché à terme pour le rendre plus acceswible au public. Il s'agirait particulièrement He ne plus imposer aux agents l'obligation de Héposer en main du Comité la marge fixée, Etant donné que les compensations hebdomaHaire et extraordinaire constituent un acte de
elle défense que le dépôt d'une marge est inutile...
On annonce la nomination de M. le Marquis de Reverseaux, ancien ambassadear au Caire momme membre français da Conseil d'Administration de la Banque d'Athènes.
Il entre dans le conseil de la Banque d'Athemes, à titre de représentant de la Banque "l'Union Parisienne" dont il est administraeur.

Carnet de l'actionnaire. MM. les setionnaires de l'United Egyptian "ands Ltd." sont informés qu'au cas de non., naiement jusqu'au 30 Novembre 1907 des ommes dues par eux pour le premier appel de onds fait le 30 Mars dernier, ils seront passiles d'un intérêt de 9% l'an à partir de cette late.
Les versements arriérés doivent être effee inés à la National Bank, sa Caire ou à Alex ndrie

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."
UNITED HOTELS OF EGYPT LIMITE

NOTICB IS HEREBY GIVEN that Extraordinary General Meeting of the "Unit Hotels of Egypt Limited" will be held att Egyptian offices of the Company at No. 21 R Emad el Dine, Cairo on Thursday the 28th di of November 1907 at 4 o'clock in the afterno for the purpose of considering, and if thoug fit, passing the following resolutions : (1) that the Company be wound up voluntari |(2) that Mr. Adolph Cattani and Mr. Je
Joannides be and are hereby appoint liquidators for the parpose of such win ing-up at such remuneration as shall
fixed by the meeting. (8) that the said liquidators be and are here

authorised as soon as they convenient can out of the Assets of the Company aft providing for all liabilities, to return t sum of six shillings per share in respect each Ordinary Share in the Company Capital, upon which the sum of ten shi ings has been paid up, and to return i respect of each Ordinary Share in th Company's Capital upon which the sum five shillings only has been paid up th sum of one shilling per share, less interes on the five shillings due in respect of suc sbares at the rate of nine per cent pe annum from the fifth day of April 1907 the date when the resolution for winding
up shall be confirmed. (4) That without prejudice to the gener

powers vested in the said liquidators fe winding up the Company they be and an hereby especially authorised to sell th lands and properties of the Company an at such time or times at such price and o such terms and conditions as they shal

in their absolute discretion think fit. Should the above resolutions be passed by the requisite majority they will be submitte for confirmation as special resolutions to second Extraordinary General Meeting, whicl which will be subsequently convened.
Dated this nineteenth day of Novembe 1907. By order of the Board
N. MORRISON.
Secretary in Egypt N.B. Attention is called to clause 80 of the Company's Articles of Association, namely:

"No member shall be entitled to be present " or vote on any question, either personally *" or by proxy, or as proxy for another member " at any General meeting or upon a poll, on " be reckoned in a quorum, whilst any call on " other sum shall be due and payable to the " Company by such member." 81843-9-
Administration des Chemins de fer
de l'Etat Egyptien

AVIS L'Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Publie qu'il sera procédé le Landi vingt cinq Novembre courant, à neuf heures da matin, au bureau de Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Généraux de Boulae (Caire), à la vente aux enchères publiques, suivant Kaimat Mazad, de dix-sept vieilles machines à écrire (typewriters) qui se trouvent aux dits Magasins, ou on peat les exaininer et prendre en même temps connaissance des conditions de leur vente, chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à une heure p.m. les Dimanches et jours fériés erceptés.
On peut également prendre connaissance des conditions de vente susdites au Bureau de Mr. l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary a (Ale xandrie) aux heures ci-dessus indiquées.

Pour etre admis à concourir, le soumissionDaire devrs, au préalable, verser la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration au Caire une somme de LE. 5 (Cinq Livres Egyptiennes) titre de dépôt provisoire que l'enchérissear declaré adjudicataire aura à parfaire séance tenante jusqu'à concurrence de dix pour cent du montant de l'offre agréée.
L'Adjudicataire de l'ensemble ou d'une partie des dites machines aura à les enlever å ses frais dans les vingt quatre heures qui suivent la date d'acceptation de son offre.

Des offres pourront être faites sur papier timbré de trente millièmes si l'intéressé ne peut pas assister aux enchères publiques, et dans ce cas la soumission ainsi que le reçu da versement de dépôt provisoire seront adressés par la poste sous pli recommandé à Monsieur le Chef du Service des Magasins des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat à
Boulac (Caire) et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription saivante :
"Offre pour achat de vieilles machines écrire."
Toute offre faite ou déposée ultérieurement aa jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération.

L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter les prix les plus élevés ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser la vente. Le Caire, le 15 Novembre 1907. 31392-2-1

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXÀNDRI
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication fourniture de bancs en bois, avec pieds en fe courbé.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LEg. (vingt).
Le cahier des charges est déposé au burea des Paros et Plantations où il peut être con sulté par les intéressés tous les jours d 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sons pl cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 26 Novembre 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour Bh. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la men tion : "Soumission pour "Fourniture de bancs en bois."
Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque prévu au cahier des charges devra être verse su Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 26 novembre 9h à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée. Alexandrie, le 14 Novembre 1907.
L'Administrateur 81315-3-3
(Signé) W.P. CHATAWAY.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Le public est informé que la Municipalité prooeders à la vente aux enchères publiques au Palais Municipal (Bureau des Recettes), le Samedi 16 courant à 21 heures a.m., de :
2 chevaux
1 victoria non numérotée. Cette vente aura lieu en exécution d'une misie pratiquée à l'encontre de propriétaire.
Le prix adjugé sera payé immédiatement en plus de 2% pour droits de criée, dès la réception des objets sus-dits, réception qui doit avoir lieu le jour même de l'achat.
L'Administrateur (Signé:) W.P. CHATAWAY. 31300-8-8 Alexandrie, le 12 Novembre 1907.
